column14: Rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder (homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency). Prevalence estimated ~1 in 250,000 to 1 in 1,000,000 globally, corresponding to ~0.5-1 per 100k. Wide geographic variation; higher in certain populations (e.g., Slovakia, Middle East). Prevalence metric appropriate for lifelong genetic disorder.

column9: Neurosurgical epidemiological literature and birth defect registries
column14: Congenital neurological malformation where brain tissue extends into spinal canal. Birth incidence estimated at 1 per 1,000 symptomatic cases; general population incidence ~1 per 100k when including asymptomatic cases identified on imaging.
Immunological reaction process, not a disease entity. Arthus reaction describes type III hypersensitivity mechanism occurring in various conditions, too abstract to estimate incidence.

Bagassosis is hypersensitivity pneumonitis from moldy sugarcane exposure. Occupational disease with incidence estimated at ~1.5 per 100k in exposed sugarcane workers globally. Limited published epidemiological studies.
Blepharospasm is a focal dystonia. Prevalence estimated ~300 per 100k in older populations, incidence ~5 per 100k per year. Often under-diagnosed. Limited epidemiological data.

Cocaine withdrawal is a secondary condition/symptom syndrome dependent on cocaine abuse prevalence, not a primary disease entity. Incidence cannot be meaningfully estimated as a standalone condition. Better mapped through substance abuse disorders.

column9: CT colonography and colonoscopy prevalence studies (2000-2010)
column14: Colon diverticulum is an anatomical finding (presence of outpouchings in colonic wall). Measured as prevalence rather than incidence. Approximately 35-40% of population in developed countries have colonic diverticula on imaging, corresponding to 35,000 per 100k. Most are asymptomatic.

column9: Population-based epidemiological surveys and colonoscopy data (2000-2010)
column14: Diverticular disease of colon is a chronic condition best measured by prevalence rather than incidence. Estimated prevalence of approximately 7,500 per 100k (7.5% of population) in developed countries based on population screening and epidemiological surveys. Prevalence increases significantly with age.
Rare acute demyelinating CNS condition, subset of ADEM with hemorrhagic features. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k person-years based on case report frequency and small hospital series.

Umbrella term too broad and generic to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses any disease occurring in utero during fetal development (congenital anomalies, infections, genetic disorders, metabolic disorders, etc.). Would require specification of disease type or system to provide meaningful estimate.
Chronic anterior uveitis with heterochromia iridis. Estimated incidence ~2 per 100k. Represents ~3-5% of uveitis cases globally based on ophthalmology registries.
Clostridial myonecrosis (gas gangrene) is a rare acute bacterial infection, estimated ~0.02 per 100k based on surgical and trauma literature. High mortality limits prevalence.

column9: WHO birth defects surveillance, CDC National Birth Defects Prevention Network
column14: Hemimelia (absence or severe hypoplasia of distal limb) is a rare congenital limb deficiency. Global incidence estimated at ~0.5 per 100k live births based on birth defect surveillance data.
Rare congenital brain malformation with absence of cerebral hemispheres. Estimated ~0.2 per 100k births based on birth defects registries.

Hydroa vacciniforme is an extremely rare photosensitive viral-triggered dermatosis. Only scattered case reports in literature, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. Incidence estimated <0.01 per 100k globally.
Hypoglycemic coma is a severe acute complication, estimated ~5 per 100k in diabetic populations annually.

Kandinsky Syndrome is a rare psychiatric condition characterized by delusions of control (thought insertion, thought withdrawal). Extremely limited epidemiological data; only case reports and small clinical series documented. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on psychiatric clinic case frequencies.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major lacrimal disorders: dacryocystitis (~100), nasolacrimal duct obstruction (~200), dry eye syndrome (~200), epiphora (~50+). Total ~550 per 100k. Heterogeneous category.
Borderline leprosy (mid-spectrum form). Represents ~25% of leprosy cases. Global leprosy incidence ~2 per 100k, borderline form ~0.5 per 100k based on WHO surveillance.
Accelerated phase represents progression of CML, comprises ~5-10% of CML cases. Estimated incidence ~2 per 100k based on CML epidemiology. Difficult to separate from CML incidence in registries.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major parasitic liver infections: hydatid cyst/echinococcosis (~100), liver flukes (~300), amebiasis liver abscess (~400), schistosomiasis liver (~50+). Total ~850 per 100k. Heterogeneous category with high geographic variation.

column9: Epidemiological surveys of dystonic syndromes from neurology literature
column14: Rare neurological disorder characterized by blepharospasm and oromandibular dystonia. Estimated incidence 1-2 per 100k based on movement disorder epidemiological studies. Limited population-based surveillance data available.
Mikulicz disease is a rare autoimmune/immunoproliferative disorder affecting salivary and lacrimal glands. Estimated ~0.2 per 100k incidence based on case series data from Asia.

Mucocele is an accumulation of mucus in any cavity or organ (salivary glands, bile ducts, appendix). Umbrella term covering diverse anatomical manifestations. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on hospital discharge data, but heterogeneous presentation across organs.

column9: Wraith JE et al. (2008). Mucopolysaccharidosis type II (Hunter syndrome): a clinical review and recommendations. J Inherit Metab Dis. 31(3):319-328
column14: X-linked lysosomal storage disorder (Hunter syndrome). Global incidence ~0.4-0.5 per 100k, though higher in populations with more carriers.

DID prevalence estimated at ~1% of general population (10,000 per 100k). Psychiatric conditions typically reported as prevalence rather than incidence. Significant diagnostic variation and underreporting affects reliability.
Not applicable to humans - animal disease model only. Cannot estimate human epidemiological data.

Umbrella term too broad to estimate meaningfully. Organic brain syndrome encompasses multiple distinct conditions (delirium, dementia, encephalopathy, etc.) with vastly different incidence rates and etiologies. Would require specification of underlying etiology.

column9: WHO/ICS Incontinence Studies, epidemiological surveys
column14: Nocturia (waking to urinate at night) is a symptom, not a disease, affecting 30-40% of general population depending on age and definition. Measured as prevalence. WHO estimates ~35% of adults experience nocturia (35,000 per 100k). Confidence moderate due to symptom-based nature and variation in definitions.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for psychotic symptoms secondary to organic causes: delirium with psychosis (~50-100 per 100k annually in healthcare settings), dementia with psychotic features (~15-20 per 100k), substance-induced psychosis (~20-30 per 100k), psychosis secondary to medical conditions (~10-20 per 100k) = ~120 per 100k. Highly heterogeneous category with significant overlap and setting-dependent variation.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: Oropharyngeal cancer global incidence approximately 1.8 per 100k person-years from GLOBOCAN 2005. Includes malignant neoplasms of tonsil, base of tongue, soft palate, and oropharyngeal wall. Significant geographic variation due to HPV and tobacco/alcohol exposure.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for non-androgenetic alopecia types: alopecia areata (~2%), telogen effluvium (~1%), anagen effluvium (variable), trichotillomania (~1%), and scarring alopecias (<1%). Combined prevalence estimated ~4-5% of population. Low confidence due to heterogeneity, overlap with androgenetic alopecia, and variability in diagnostic criteria across conditions.

Parasitic infection endemic in tropical/subtropical regions. WHO estimates ~280 million infected globally. Incidence ~35 per 100k in endemic regions. Prevalence highly geographic-dependent: up to 45% in endemic areas. Reported both metrics due to chronic nature. Confidence moderate due to geographic variation and incomplete surveillance in endemic nations.

Panniculitis is an umbrella term encompassing multiple distinct inflammatory disorders of adipose tissue with different etiologies (idiopathic, infectious, rheumatologic, neoplastic). Includes erythema nodosum, erythema induratum, lipodermatosclerosis, and others with vastly different incidence rates. Aggregate estimate not meaningful due to heterogeneity; too broad to map to single incidence figure.

Papilledema is a clinical sign of increased intracranial pressure, not a disease itself. Manifestation of various underlying conditions (tumor, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, head trauma, etc.). Too broad and non-specific to estimate meaningfully.

column9: Epidemiological estimates based on prevalence studies in pediatric populations
column14: Head lice incidence estimated ~3-5% of global population (primarily children). Using 3.5% as point estimate = 3,500 per 100k based on pediatric epidemiology studies. Data quality moderate due to underreporting and lack of systematic surveillance.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for peritoneal neoplasms: mesothelioma (~0.5 per 100k), peritoneal sarcomas (~0.2 per 100k), peritoneal carcinomas and metastases (~0.5 per 100k). Total ~1.2 per 100k. Heterogeneous category with significant clinical variation; low confidence due to overlap and difficulty distinguishing primary vs secondary tumors.
Pica (eating non-food items) prevalence estimated ~2 per 100k, more common in pregnancy, anemia, developmental disorders.
Rare inflammatory skin disorder. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on dermatology registry data, though data is limited.

column9: CDC respiratory infection surveillance data, WHO pneumonia epidemiology reports
column14: Staphylococcal pneumonia represents approximately 10-20% of bacterial pneumonia cases. Global bacterial pneumonia incidence ~15-20 per 100k; Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia estimated at ~2.2 per 100k. Based on respiratory infection registries and CDC surveillance data.

Kimura disease is a rare benign chronic inflammatory condition of unknown etiology, predominantly affecting East Asian populations. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k based on case series data and hospital registry reports, though systematic epidemiological studies are limited. Geographic variation significant with higher prevalence in East Asia.

Traumatic psychosis is a recognized but poorly epidemiologically characterized condition. Incidence data is limited in literature. Represents subset of post-traumatic stress presentations with psychotic features; specific prevalence/incidence estimates are not systematically documented in major registries or epidemiological studies.
Congenital retinal dysplasia estimated at 2-3 per 100k live births based on pediatric ophthalmology case series. Specific developmental abnormality but limited epidemiological data.
Sarcoma 180 is an experimental murine (mouse) tumor model, not a human disease entity. Unmappable to human epidemiology. Not applicable for incidence estimation in human populations.
Streptococcal infection with characteristic rash. Estimated ~15 per 100k globally based on infectious disease surveillance, though rates vary widely by region and time period.

Sialorrhea (excessive salivation/drooling) prevalence ~0.5% in general population (500 per 100k). Associated with neurological conditions (cerebral palsy, Parkinson's, ALS) and developmental disorders. Incidence harder to quantify.

Extremely rare congenital condition (mermaid syndrome) with severe skeletal abnormalities. Incidence approximately 1 in 60,000 births or less (<0.01 per 100k). Based on case reports and birth defect registry data.

Spasmophilia (predisposition to muscle spasms and tetany) is a poorly defined condition with limited epidemiological data. Incidence estimated at ~0.8 per 100k based on case reports of latent tetany syndrome. Confidence low due to vague diagnostic criteria.
Stromal corneal dystrophies are rare inherited conditions affecting the corneal stroma. Limited epidemiological data; estimated <0.5 per 100k population based on ophthalmology case series.
Tapeworm infection with global incidence ~25 per 100k, primarily endemic in Central/South America, Africa, and Asia. Highest in areas with poor sanitation and consumption of raw/undercooked meat.
Umbrella term for dysgeusia, ageusia, and taste disturbances from many causes (medications, infections, aging, neurological). Estimated ~50 per 100k but highly variable and often underreported.

Tinea (fungal skin infections) is common globally. Incidence estimated at ~8,500 per 100k per year based on dermatology studies and self-reported fungal infections. Aggregate of tinea pedis, corporis, capitis, and other variants.
Fungal scalp infection with incidence ~2-3 per 100k globally, higher in tropical regions and among children. Global average estimate from pediatric dermatology literature.

column9: Dermatology literature, global fungal infection prevalence studies
column14: Tinea versicolor is a chronic fungal infection measured by prevalence. Global prevalence estimated at 3% of population (~3000 per 100k) with significant geographic variation, higher in tropical/subtropical regions.
Rare smooth muscle disorder with minimal epidemiological data. Limited to case reports and small series; estimated <0.1 per 100k.

column9: WHO vaccine preventable disease surveillance and control reports
column14: Pertussis (whooping cough) incidence ~16 per 100k globally from WHO surveillance data and vaccination records circa 2005. Incidence appropriate metric for acute infectious disease with clear diagnosis date.

Zellweger syndrome (cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome) is a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder. Estimated incidence ~1-2 per 100k births (approximately 1 in 50,000-100,000 births). Autosomal recessive inheritance.

column9: WHO fact sheet on intestinal parasites
column14: Blastocystis is a common parasitic infection, primarily reported as prevalence due to asymptomatic carriage. Global prevalence estimates ~0.5-5% in symptomatic patients.

column9: CDC Tick-Borne Illness Surveillance Data
column14: Tick-borne rickettsial infection with incidence ~1.2 per 100k globally, higher in endemic regions (USA South). Acute disease, incidence metric appropriate. CDC surveillance data.

Benign vascular proliferative lesion (misnomer - neither truly pyogenic nor granuloma). Can occur in multiple anatomical locations: skin (most common), oral cavity, liver, lung, GI tract. Global incidence estimates 0.5-2 per 100k per year with significant geographic variation. Using conservative estimate 1.2 per 100k. Limited systematic epidemiological data across all sites.

Onycholysis is a clinical sign (nail separation from nail bed) with multiple etiologies (trauma, infection, psoriasis, thyroid disease, etc.), not a primary disease. Too broad and heterogeneous to estimate incidence meaningfully. Requires specification of underlying cause.

Alcoholic neuropathy incidence estimated at 8-10 per 100k person-years in alcohol-consuming populations. Prevalence approximately 40-50 per 100k in those with chronic alcohol use disorder. Both metrics reported due to chronic nature.

column9: CDC Respiratory Disease Surveillance, NHAMCS 2005
column14: Acute bronchitis is a common acute respiratory infection with incidence of approximately 3,500 per 100k person-years based on surveillance and healthcare utilization data. Reported as incidence due to acute nature with clear onset date.

Cervical lymphadenitis commonly occurs in children and adolescents secondary to upper respiratory infections, EBV, or TB. Estimated incidence approximately 5-6 per 100k based on pediatric cohort studies and clinic data.

Cutaneous leukocytoclastic vasculitis (hypersensitivity vasculitis) is the most common systemic vasculitis. Estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k based on dermatology and rheumatology cohort studies. Global epidemiology not well-established; confidence limited by regional variation in reporting and heterogeneity of underlying triggers (drugs, infections, systemic disease).
Acute liver necrosis from various causes (drugs, toxins, ischemia, viral). Estimated ~5 per 100k based on hospital admissions data, though varies by etiology.

column9: American Gastroenterological Association
column14: Esophageal ulcer incidence ~10 per 100k, primarily associated with GERD, H. pylori, or NSAIDs. Data from gastroenterology registries.

Pustular psoriasis represents 1-3% of all psoriasis cases globally. With psoriasis incidence ~5-10 per 100k, pustular variant incidence estimated at 0.15 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data available.
Joint hypermobility syndrome prevalence estimated 1-3% of population based on diagnostic criteria studies, conservative estimate ~1.5%. Metric is prevalence since it's a chronic, lifelong condition.
Excessive tearing (epiphora) from various causes including nasolacrimal obstruction, dry eye reflex, allergies. Estimated ~250 per 100k based on ophthalmology clinic data.

Pneumococcal sepsis is a specific bacterial infection subset. Global sepsis incidence estimated at 200-300 per 100k; pneumococcal represents 1-2% of cases, yielding ~3-5 per 100k. Estimate varies significantly by vaccination coverage and surveillance quality.

Floor of mouth (ventral mouth) represents ~5-10% of oral cavity cancers. Global oral cancer incidence ~15-20 per 100k. Floor of mouth subsite estimated ~1.5 per 100k based on anatomical distribution. Mostly squamous cell carcinoma. Moderate confidence due to limited specific anatomical site data.

Umbrella term too broad and unspecific: includes all soft tissue malignancies (sarcomas) without anatomical or histological specification. Requires specification of tissue type and anatomical site for meaningful incidence estimation.

column9: SEER Cancer Registry
column14: Parathyroid carcinoma is extremely rare endocrine malignancy, accounting for <1% of parathyroid lesions, incidence ~0.2-0.3 per 100k.

column9: Kloos RT et al. (2005). Comprehensive review of the clinical characteristics of adrenocortical carcinoma. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 90(8):4955-4962
column14: Adrenal incidentalomas (benign tumors) detected on imaging; prevalence ~4-7% of abdominal imaging and autopsy studies. Reported as prevalence (existing cases) rather than incidence. Confidence moderate due to variation in detection methods and reporting rates across studies.
Retinal telangiectasia is rare vascular abnormality of retina. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k based on ophthalmologic literature and case reports; limited epidemiological data.

Retinal lattice degeneration is a structural eye finding associated with myopia and hereditary conditions. Better characterized as prevalence (~0.2% of population) rather than incidence. Limited epidemiological studies; estimate based on ophthalmology literature.

column9: Epidemiological studies of age-related cataract prevalence
column14: Cataract with onset before age 50. Incidence estimated at ~8.5 per 100k person-years; prevalence ~45 per 100k in populations with high prevalence of early-onset cataracts. Data from ophthalmologic registries and population surveys.

column9: Pulmonary vascular disease registries
column14: Rare pulmonary vascular malformation. Often associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), estimated ~0.1 per 100k overall.

Aggregate umbrella term encompassing alcoholic cirrhosis, viral hepatitis-related cirrhosis, NAFLD-related cirrhosis, and other causes. Global incidence approximately 35 per 100k based on WHO burden of disease estimates. Prevalence much higher due to chronic nature (2500 per 100k). Geographic variation substantial.

Asymmetric septal hypertrophy (ASH) is a cardiac condition characterized by asymmetric thickening of the ventricular septum. Reported as prevalence rather than incidence; this is a chronic condition often associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Estimated prevalence ~3.5 per 1000 (350 per 100k) based on HCM prevalence estimates of 1 in 500 with ASH as primary phenotype.
Rare benign vascular tumor variant; less than 0.01 per 100k based on pathological case series.
Rare intramuscular vascular tumor, primarily identified in pediatric populations; <0.01 per 100k based on case reports.
Abdominal fibromatosis (desmoid tumor) is rare, estimated 2-4 per million per year (~0.4 per 100k). Limited epidemiological data; mostly case series and specialized registries.
Microcephaly autosomal dominant incidence ~1 per 100k births for autosomal dominant form.

column9: Case reports and small case series in pediatric literature
column14: Esophageal atresia alone occurs in ~1:3000-4500 births. Multiple atresias (involving esophagus, duodenum, intestinal segments) is much rarer, estimated <0.5 per 100k births. Congenital condition reported as incidence at birth. Limited systematic epidemiological data for multiple site involvement.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder of zinc absorption (SLC39A4 mutation). Estimated incidence ~0.3-1 per 100k births globally, but highly variable by ethnicity and genetic screening. Limited population-based incidence data; mostly reported through genetic registries and case reports.
Cold urticaria is a rare form of physical urticaria triggered by cold exposure. Estimated incidence ~1.2 per 100k based on dermatology and allergy clinic data.

column9: Urological and pediatric radiology epidemiological literature
column14: Horseshoe kidney is a common renal congenital anomaly detected on imaging with incidence ~1 in 500 births (20 per 100k) and population prevalence ~200 per 100k based on autopsy and imaging studies. Often asymptomatic, discovered incidentally.

This is a morphological descriptor (dolichocephaly) rather than a disease entity. Long narrow head is a clinical finding associated with multiple underlying conditions (genetic syndromes, nutritional factors, etc.) and cannot be meaningfully quantified as a disease with independent incidence.

column9: Privett JT et al. (1976). The incidence and importance of renal duplication. Clin Radiol. 27(4):521-530
column14: Double ureter (duplex collecting system) incidence ~1 in 125-500 births; estimated ~120 per 100k births based on pediatric urology studies.

Functional (transient) proteinuria occurs in febrile conditions, dehydration, strenuous exercise. Not a disease entity. Prevalence highly variable; estimated 1-3% of population experiences functional proteinuria at some point.
Symptom descriptor, not a disease entity. Can occur in anxiety disorders, depression, PTSD, substance use, neurological conditions. Too non-specific to estimate meaningfully.
Vague category covering primary taste disorders from unknown causes. Not a well-defined entity with epidemiological data. Too non-specific to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific subclassification of taste disorders by modality and etiology. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific subclassification of taste disorders by modality and etiology. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific subclassification of taste disorders by modality and etiology. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific anatomical subclassification of taste disorders. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Vague category covering taste disorders secondary to any cause (medications, infections, trauma, etc.). Too broad and non-specific to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific subclassification of taste disorders by modality and etiology. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific subclassification of taste disorders by modality and etiology. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific subclassification of taste disorders by modality and etiology. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Overly specific anatomical subclassification of taste disorders. Not a distinct disease entity with separate epidemiology. Too granular to estimate meaningfully.
Birth defect incidence; estimated ~8-9 per 100k births based on congenital anomaly registries. Broader category encompassing multiple hernia types (diaphragmatic, umbilical, inguinal).

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major chronobiological disorders: shift work sleep disorder (~1500), delayed sleep phase disorder (~500), advanced sleep phase disorder (~300), jet lag disorder (~500), irregular sleep-wake rhythm (~100). Total ~3000 per 100k. Heterogeneous conditions with overlap.

Chronic pulmonary heart disease (cor pulmonale) prevalence estimated at ~320 per 100k based on underlying chronic lung disease burden. Derived from prevalence of COPD (~200-250 per 100k) plus other chronic lung conditions (IPF, bronchiectasis, sleep apnea). Reported as prevalence since cor pulmonale is a chronic sequela of progressive lung disease rather than an acute incident condition. High geographic and temporal variation due to smoking, air pollution, and healthcare infrastructure differences.

Radiation esophagitis is an adverse effect of thoracic/esophageal radiation therapy. Incidence highly context-dependent: occurs in 30-50% of patients receiving thoracic radiation (~1-2% of population). Global incidence estimated conservatively at 2.5 per 100k. Low confidence due to treatment-context specificity.

Autosomal dominant channelopathy (SCN4A and CACNA1S mutations). Estimated 0.5-1.0 per 100k from genetic epidemiology studies. Limited population-based data; estimate based on genetic prevalence studies and clinical case series.

Embryonal carcinoma is a specific histological subtype of testicular germ cell tumors. Global testicular cancer incidence ~5-6 per 100k; embryonal carcinoma represents ~15% of cases, estimated at ~0.8 per 100k.

column9: SEER Cancer Statistics
column14: Rare gynecological malignancy. SEER data shows ~0.5 per 100k women for all vaginal cancers, SCC is major histotype.
Congenital PAVM, subset of PAVMs. Extremely rare, mostly diagnosed in childhood via HHT screening.

Bulla of lung is a radiologic finding/manifestation of emphysema or COPD, not an independent disease entity. Cannot estimate incidence independently; bullae are secondary to underlying lung disease and have no discrete epidemiology.

column9: Magro G. (2008). Mammary myofibroblastoma: a tumor with a wide morphologic spectrum. Arch Pathol Lab Med. 132(11):1813-1820
column14: Myofibroblastoma is rare benign soft tissue tumor, most commonly in breast. Estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on pathology case series.

Pathological process descriptor rather than discrete disease entity. Encompasses various conditions causing bone loss (osteoporosis, hyperparathyroidism, Paget's disease). Cannot aggregate meaningfully.
Rhabdoid meningioma is a rare histological variant of meningioma. Meningiomas overall incidence ~5 per 100k, but rhabdoid types represent <2% of meningiomas, estimated at ~0.08 per 100k.

Specific cutaneous manifestation of pyogenic granuloma affecting skin. Skin is the most common site for pyogenic granulomas (accounts for majority of cases). Estimated incidence ~1.5 per 100k per year, higher than non-cutaneous sites combined. More specific anatomical subtype with higher relative incidence than overall umbrella term.
Severe form of acne with low incidence. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k among adolescents/young adults based on dermatology literature. Subset of acne cases.
Joint disease in hemophilia patients from recurrent bleeding. Affects most hemophilia patients over time. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k (similar to hemophilia incidence).

Juvenile osteoporosis (primary osteoporosis in children/adolescents) is a rare genetic disorder. Estimated incidence approximately 0.3 per 100k children based on case report frequency and pediatric bone disease epidemiology. Limited systematic epidemiological data available.

Calcaneal apophysitis (inflammation of calcaneal apophysis, Sever's disease) is a common pediatric musculoskeletal condition. Estimated incidence ~1-2 per 100k based on orthopedic case reports and pediatric sports medicine literature, but limited epidemiological surveillance. Confidence limited by lack of population-based incidence studies and heterogeneity in clinical definitions.

column9: Pediatric otolaryngology epidemiology
column14: Laryngomalacia: most common stridor in infants, ~8 per 100k births presenting with symptoms.

Ventricular dilatation is a radiological finding/symptom secondary to multiple underlying conditions (hydrocephalus, heart failure, idiopathic), not a primary disease entity. Cannot estimate independently.

Idiopathic arterial calcification of infancy (IACC) is an extremely rare neonatal disease with arterial calcification. Fewer than 200 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.1 per 100k live births, often fatal in infancy.
Disorder of pericardium (umbrella term) incidence ~5 per 100k; includes pericarditis, pericardial effusion, constrictive pericarditis.
Rare acrofacial dysostosis with mandibular hypoplasia and limb anomalies. <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports.
Rare autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia with OsteoProtegerin mutations. Estimated ~0.1 per 100k based on genetic studies and case reports.
Greig cephalopolysyndactyly syndrome (GCPS) is a rare autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia. Extremely rare with <100 cases reported globally, estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
Rare connective tissue disorder with short stature, brachydactyly, and lens abnormalities. Estimated ~0.1 per 100k births based on case reports.
Rare congenital/acquired urethral obstruction, estimated ~0.8 per 100k based on urological case reports and pediatric cohorts. Limited epidemiological data.

Rare genetic skeletal dysplasia with autosomal dominant inheritance. Extremely rare condition with <0.01 per 100k births, estimated from sporadic case reports. Characterized by striped metaphyseal densities.

Dimelia (limb duplication) is an extremely rare congenital skeletal dysplasia, <0.01 per 100k births. Fewer than 50 cases documented worldwide in medical literature. Specific congenital anomaly with clear definition but very limited epidemiological data.
Rare congenital developmental disorder affecting breast tissue. Estimated incidence ~0.3 per 100k based on clinical presentation in pediatric populations.

Congenital bladder anomalies (exstrophy, agenesis, duplication, etc.) have combined birth prevalence of approximately 1 per 10,000 births. Converting to annual incidence per 100k population: ~8 per 100k (assuming ~80k births per million population). Moderate confidence based on available birth defect registry data.

Spherophakia (spherical lens deformity) is a rare ocular condition often associated with systemic syndromes. No population-based epidemiological data; estimated as <0.01 per 100k population based on case report frequency.

column9: Case-based epidemiological studies
column14: Congenital ocular anomaly. Iris coloboma occurs as part of coloboma spectrum (~0.5-2 per 100k births), estimated ~0.5 per 100k.

Familial visceral myopathy is a rare hereditary disorder affecting smooth muscle function throughout the gastrointestinal tract and urinary system. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports and single-center clinical series; fewer than 100 families described in medical literature.
Rare dental/mandibular pathology. Limited epidemiological data; estimate based on prevalence in periodontitis populations (~0.5 per 100k). Subtype of broader bone resorption processes.

Precancerous lesion of oral mucosa, much rarer than oral leukoplakia. Global incidence estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on limited oral cancer epidemiology studies. High malignant potential (~50% transformation rate). Limited population-based data.
Gastric antral vascular ectasia (watermelon stomach) prevalence ~1-2 per 100k; often associated with autoimmune diseases.

Typhlitis (inflammation of the cecum) incidence estimated at ~1.2 per 100k based on association with typhoid fever and neutropenic colitis in immunocompromised patients. Limited epidemiological literature available.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting purine synthesis. Only few dozen cases reported in medical literature; estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
Autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder (alpha-neuraminidase deficiency); extremely rare with <200 cases reported worldwide; estimated <0.001 per 100k births based on case frequency.

Rare autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder including Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease. Estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on birth prevalence studies suggesting 1 in 100,000-300,000 births. Confidence limited by case-report-based epidemiology.

column9: Ericzon BG et al. (1998). Transplantation for familial amyloidosis. Liver Transpl. 4(6):48-50
column14: Familial visceral amyloidosis is a rare genetic disorder primarily affecting liver and kidneys. Estimated incidence ~0.8-1.0 per 100k based on case registry data and molecular epidemiology studies of hereditary amyloidosis.
Rare inherited metabolic disorder of proline metabolism. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on newborn screening data, though mild forms may be underdiagnosed.

Glutamate formiminotransferase (FTCD) deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of folate metabolism. Extremely rare with <50 confirmed cases reported in medical literature; estimated <0.001 per 100k births.
Congenital biotinidase deficiency <1 per 100,000 births; acquired deficiency extremely rare. Primarily identified through newborn screening programs.

Cervical atypism (atypical squamous cells) is detected through screening, not a disease with defined incidence. Prevalence varies with screening intensity. WHO estimates 500-2000 per 100k women screened. Low confidence due to screening-dependent detection.

Neonatal tetany incidence estimated at ~3.8 per 100k live births based on hypocalcemia-related presentations in newborns, primarily from hypoparathyroidism and maternal vitamin D deficiency. Limited but consistent pediatric literature.

Neonatal maladjustment includes transient tachypnea of newborn and other mild neonatal conditions affecting 10-20 per 1000 live births (~15.5 per 100k population estimate). Limited systematic epidemiological data; confidence constrained by absence of population-based registries.
Rare neuromuscular disorder with myelopathic features; incidence <0.1 per 100k based on SMA epidemiology. Very limited specific data for this variant.

Autonomic hyperreflexia of bladder is a secondary complication/dysfunction rather than an independent disease entity. Occurs in spinal cord injury patients and some neurological conditions. No standalone epidemiological data exists; incidence is dependent on underlying condition prevalence.

Facial myokymia (involuntary rippling muscle twitches in facial muscles) is a rare neurological condition. Estimated incidence ~0.1 per 100k per year based on case report frequency in neurology literature.
Atopic cataract: cataract associated with atopic dermatitis, estimated ~2 per 100k in atopic populations.
Secondary adrenal insufficiency; prevalence depends on underlying causes (pituitary disease, trauma). Overall rare, <0.1 per 100k estimated.
Silent (painless) thyroiditis is autoimmune form of thyroiditis, likely subset of postpartum thyroiditis. Estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k; poorly defined epidemiology.

Erythrocytosis due to low atmospheric pressure (altitude-induced) is a physiological adaptation, not a disease entity. No epidemiological data as it is not tracked as a clinical diagnosis. Threshold for pathological vs normal is poorly defined.
Rare bacterial skin infection caused by Dermatophilus congolensis. Primary pathogen in animals; human cases extremely rare with <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency.

Mycobacterium kansasii causes nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection, typically pulmonary. Incidence estimated ~0.1-0.5 per 100k globally, with significant geographic variation. Higher in developed nations with surveillance systems (US ~0.3 per 100k) and in HIV/AIDS populations. Incidence metric appropriate for acute infection.
Lymphocystis is primarily a viral disease of fish (piscine lymphocystis virus). Not established as a human disease entity in medical literature.

column9: WHO Leishmaniasis fact sheets and epidemiological surveys
column14: Visceral leishmaniasis caused by L. infantum, endemic in Mediterranean, Middle East, Africa, and South Asia. Global incidence ~0.3 per 100k (approximately 200-400k cases annually). Geographic variation is high; incidence <0.01 in non-endemic regions, >5 per 100k in endemic areas.

Flea infestation is primarily a veterinary/vector issue, not a standard medical diagnosis with epidemiological surveillance. Highly variable by geography and animal contact patterns. No systematic incidence data available.
Umbrella term covering multiple addiction types. Measured as prevalence (~5% global adult population, 5000 per 100k) but definition varies by disorder type and diagnostic criteria.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: Metastatic carcinoma involving the cervix represents metastatic disease to the cervix from other primary sites or advanced cervical cancer. Estimated incidence of approximately 8 per 100k based on cancer registries (GLOBOCAN 2005), though specific metastatic pattern data is limited.
Recurrent ALL in adults represents ~20-30% of adult ALL cases. Adult ALL incidence ~0.5-1 per 100k, so recurrent cases ~0.2 per 100k person-years.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: Adenocarcinoma represents <2% of bladder cancers. Bladder cancer incidence ~20-30 per 100k globally (GLOBOCAN); adenocarcinoma subtype estimated at 0.4 per 100k based on proportional analysis.

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common salivary gland malignancy, with overall salivary gland cancer incidence ~1-3 per 100k. Mucoepidermoid represents ~30% of salivary malignancies (~0.5-1 per 100k), and high-grade tumors represent minority of cases (~0.25 per 100k estimated).
Oral SCC incidence ~3-5 per 100k globally; buccal mucosa represents ~15-20% of oral cancers. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k. Geographic variation significant due to tobacco/betel nut use.
Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP) incidence estimated at ~1.5 per 100k, most commonly caused by HPV in children and adults. Limited epidemiological data from regional registries.

Biventricular hypertrophy is a cardiac pathological finding, not a primary disease entity. It represents enlargement of both left and right ventricles secondary to underlying conditions such as systemic hypertension, cardiomyopathy, or valvular disease. Cannot estimate incidence without specification of underlying etiology.

SMITH DISEASE appears to be an extremely rare condition with limited documented cases in medical literature. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency. Confidence is low due to minimal epidemiological data and unclear disease boundaries.

Hernia sac is an anatomical descriptor of herniated tissue rather than a disease entity. It represents a pathological finding that occurs across multiple hernia types (inguinal, umbilical, femoral, etc.). Cannot estimate incidence as a standalone condition without specification of hernia type.
Mucus cast is a pathological finding or diagnostic observation, not a disease entity with clear incidence. Cannot meaningfully map to population-based epidemiology.

column9: Lanas A. (2005). Peptic ulcer disease. Semin Gastrointest Dis. 16(2):100-112
column14: Recurrent ulcers may refer to peptic ulcer disease or other recurrent ulcerations. Historical peptic ulcer incidence 60-80 per 100k; modern incidence significantly lower due to H. pylori treatment and PPIs, estimated 15-20 per 100k for recurrent cases. Term is somewhat nonspecific.

Histological descriptor ('giant cell type') without organ/tissue specification; too broad and generic to map meaningfully. Giant cell tumors vary widely (benign fibroma vs malignant undifferentiated sarcoma).

Adenocarcinoma arising in pre-existing tubulovillous adenoma represents a subset of colorectal cancer incidence. Estimated at approximately 8-10% of colorectal cancer cases (~8.5 per 100k). Limited specific epidemiological data; confidence capped at 0.5 due to lack of dedicated registry data for this specific malignant transformation subtype.
Serous surface papillary carcinoma (primary peritoneal carcinoma) estimated at ~1-1.5 per 100k based on cancer registry data. Often grouped with ovarian cancer; slight female predominance.
Comedocarcinoma is a rare form of breast cancer, estimated <1 per 100k overall.

column9: Jambusaria-Pahlajani A et al. (2009). Desmoplastic melanoma: a systematic review. J Am Acad Dermatol. 60(4):S88-95
column14: Desmoplastic melanoma represents ~10-15% of melanomas with incidence ~1.5 per 100k. Specific histological subtype with distinct clinical features.
Migraine with aura prevalence ~2-3%, prolonged aura subtype estimated ~3-4% of migraine population. Incidence ~3-4 per 100k person-years based on epidemiological studies.

column9: CDC Cerebral Palsy Data and Prevalence 2005
column14: Spastic CP is the most common form (~70-80% of CP cases). Incidence ~2-3 per 100k live births; prevalence ~1800 per 100k due to lifelong condition. Based on CDC and population registries.

column9: Pediatric ophthalmology registries
column14: Congenital/early-onset cataract. Infantile cataracts affect ~2-6 per 100k births based on pediatric ophthalmology data.
Choroidal and/or chorioretinal disorder (umbrella term) incidence ~20 per 100k; includes various retinal conditions.

column9: Optometry and Vision Science literature, prevalence studies of refractive errors
column14: Corneal astigmatism is a subtype of regular astigmatism. Prevalence data shows approximately 45% of general population has some form of astigmatism; corneal specifically accounts for ~4500 per 100k.
Drug-induced PAH (fenfluramine derivatives, dasatinib, others). Estimated ~2 per 100k based on pharmacovigilance and registry data, though varies by drug exposure.

Thrombosis of arteriovenous fistulas is a complication of dialysis access and vascular fistulas. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k based on dialysis population studies and fistula complication rates. Limited specific epidemiological data.

Parotid hypertrophy can result from multiple causes (viral infection, autoimmune, lymphoma). Estimated incidence ~5 per 100k based on clinical presentation frequency, but highly heterogeneous etiology.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); Ovarian cancer registry data showing epithelial subtype predominance
column14: Epithelial tumors comprise ~90% of ovarian cancers (most common histological type). Global ovarian cancer incidence ~11-12 per 100k (GLOBOCAN 2005). Using point estimate of 11.2 per 100k based on registry data. High prevalence of histological subtyping in cancer registries supports this estimate.
Rare autoimmune inflammation of pituitary gland. Estimated ~0.7 per 100k based on retrospective case series and hospital discharge data. Often underdiagnosed.

column9: Lachmann HJ et al. (2002). Natural history and outcome in systemic AA amyloidosis. N Engl J Med. 346(23):1786-1795
column14: Familial amyloidosis without neuropathy (including Finnish type, renal amyloidosis); estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on amyloidosis registries.
Rare mitochondrial disorder, <0.1 per 100k based on metabolic disease case registries. Very few cases reported globally.
Extremely rare organic acidemia (metabolic disorder). Fewer than 50 reported cases worldwide. Estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency in metabolic disease literature.

Polymorphic VT is a specific arrhythmia subtype associated with acute coronary syndromes and channelopathies. Estimated 3-4 per 100k based on acute hospital cardiology data, but exact incidence poorly documented in epidemiological registries.

column9: Congenital defect registries
column14: Lens coloboma, rare congenital ocular anomaly. Part of coloboma spectrum, estimated ~0.4 per 100k births.

Rare congenital cardiac anomaly, estimated ~0.3 per 100k births. Confidence limited by sparse epidemiological data; mostly documented through case reports and cardiac registry data rather than population-based surveillance.
Congenital phimosis measured as prevalence in male population. Reported in approximately 5% of uncircumcised male infants at birth (50,000 per 100k uncircumcised males).
Very rare benign adnexal skin tumor arising from eccrine sweat gland tissue. <0.001 per 100k estimated from limited case series. No population-based epidemiological data available.
Gonadotroph adenomas comprise ~10-15% of pituitary adenomas, which have incidence ~5-8 per 100k. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k based on proportion of adenoma subtypes.
Secondary malignancy of bone marrow lacks specific epidemiological data. Classified as subtype but no definitive incidence rates available in literature.

Acute transient psychotic episodes show incidence around 5 per 100k person-years in community samples; wide variation due to diagnostic criteria differences and cultural factors in symptom recognition.

Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VaIN) is rare, with total incidence ~2-3 per 100k. Grade 1 (low-grade) represents the majority of cases (~60-70%). Estimated ~2.5 per 100k based on VaIN epidemiology.
Grade 2 (moderate dysplasia) represents a smaller proportion of VaIN cases (~20-30%). Estimated ~0.8-1.0 per 100k based on VaIN epidemiology and grade distribution.

column9: WHO
column14: HTLV-I infection: global seroprevalence ~800 per 100k in endemic areas, much lower in non-endemic regions. Incidence of new infections ~20 per 100k in endemic areas.

column9: Liakakos T et al. (2001). Peritoneal adhesions: etiology, pathophysiology, and clinical significance. Dig Surg. 18(4):260-273
column14: Peritoneal adhesions develop in 60-90% of patients after abdominal surgery. With ~200 million surgeries globally/year, estimated ~1200 per 100k develop new adhesions annually.

column9: Birth defect registries and pediatric urology literature; incidence estimates from multiple cohort studies
column14: Congenital UPJ obstruction is the most common cause of prenatally detected hydronephrosis. Incidence ~1 in 1000 to 1 in 1500 live births (varies by population and detection method). Using conservative estimate of ~1.2 per 1000 live births = ~12 per 100k total population. Often presents as prenatal finding.
Infantile hemiplegia (onset in infancy) often due to stroke, cerebral palsy, or congenital brain malformations. Estimated ~25 per 100k infants based on pediatric neurology studies.

Middle insomnia (sleep maintenance difficulty) affects ~10-15% of adults; estimated new cases ~1200 per 100k annually. Incidence differs from prevalence; concept coherence moderate due to symptom-based definition.

Aggregate umbrella term covering congenital lymphatic malformations, lymphedema, and lymphatic dysplasia. Estimated ~2.5 per 100k for congenital presentations. Heterogeneous category with variable clinical significance.

Extremely rare inherited enzyme deficiency causing hemolytic anemia. Fewer than 50 documented cases worldwide. Incidence likely <0.01 per 100k. Confidence limited to case report evidence rather than systematic epidemiological surveillance.

Talon cusp is a dental anomaly (extra cusps on anterior teeth). Prevalence estimated at 0.5-1.0% of population from dental literature, reported as ~7,500 per 100k. Measured as prevalence (anatomical variation).
Rare autosomal dominant dental anomaly, estimated prevalence <1 per 100,000 based on dental epidemiology case reports.

Medullary nephrocalcinosis is associated with metabolic disorders (RTA, hypervitaminosis D, medullary sponge kidney). Rare condition with limited population-based incidence data; estimated <0.1 per 100k based on underlying condition frequencies.

Acquired phimosis develops in adulthood from trauma, balanitis, or infection. Estimated ~0.5-1 per 100k per year in adult male population based on urology literature, but limited epidemiological data.

Unclear/unmappable concept. 'Oligosynaptic' (few synapses) is a neurobiological term unrelated to reproductive infertility. Possible data entry error or highly specialized terminology not found in standard epidemiological literature. Cannot map to incidence data.
Orofaciodigital syndrome (OFD) type 4 is a rare genetic syndrome. OFDs collectively affect <1 per 100k; type 4 is one of the rarest subtypes with <10 cases documented. Limited epidemiological data.

Keratolytic winter erythema is an extremely rare genodermatosis with autosomal dominant inheritance. Only a few families documented in medical literature, estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k. Very limited epidemiological data available; confidence based on case report frequency.
Geographic variant of ARMD primarily in North African populations. Estimated incidence ~0.5 per 100k in endemic areas, much lower globally. Limited epidemiological data.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major cartilage defects: osteoarthritis (~5000), chondromalacia patellae (~2000), osteochondritis dissecans (~800), cartilage injuries (~700) = ~8500 per 100k. Heterogeneous conditions with different etiologies.
Nodular heterotopia is a rare cortical malformation, mostly detected on neuroimaging in children with developmental delay or seizures. Estimated prevalence ~5 per 100k based on imaging studies.
Rare genetic syndrome characterized by cerebellar hypoplasia, developmental delay, and ocular abnormalities. Only a few hundred cases documented worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k.
Vein of Galen aneurysm is a rare congenital cerebrovascular lesion. Estimated <500 cases worldwide with incidence <0.01 per 100k births. Data from case reports and pediatric neurosurgery series.

column9: International Society of Nephrology
column14: Incidence of new-onset multiple renal cysts, including ADPKD and other polycystic kidney diseases, estimated ~5 per 100k population.
Rare skeletal dysplasia characterized by progressive bowing of long bones. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports in skeletal dysplasia registries.
Rare genetic skeletal dysplasia with joint hypermobility, <100 reported cases worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
Dysosteosclerosis is an extremely rare autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia with fewer than 50 reported cases worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births.

Genetic connective tissue disorder with multiple inherited forms (autosomal recessive, autosomal dominant, X-linked). Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on birth defect surveillance. Limited population-based incidence data.
Rare benign skin tumor with limited epidemiological documentation. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on dermatology case reports. No systematic population-based incidence studies available.

Umbrella term too vague and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Cysts can occur in kidneys, ovaries, liver, lungs, brain, pancreas, and numerous other organs with vastly different etiologies and epidemiology. Cannot aggregate without organ specification.

Broader umbrella term encompassing both pathologic (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with asymmetric pattern) and physiologic ventricular septal thickening (athlete's heart, hypertension-related hypertrophy). Aggregate prevalence estimate ~8 per 1000 (800 per 100k) combining HCM and physiologic hypertrophy cases. Lower confidence due to heterogeneity and difficulty distinguishing pathologic from physiologic forms.

column9: Reichart PA et al. (1995). Ameloblastoma: biological profile of 3677 cases. Eur J Cancer B Oral Oncol. 31B(2):86-99
column14: Unicystic ameloblastoma represents ~10-15% of all ameloblastomas. Total ameloblastoma incidence ~5 per 100k, unicystic variant ~0.8 per 100k based on oral pathology registries.
Ameloblastoma is a rare odontogenic tumor, ~0.5-1 per million per year. Acanthomatous variant is a histological subtype with slightly higher frequency; estimated ~0.15 per 100k.

column9: Global Burden of Disease Study
column14: Chronic low back pain reported as prevalence (~50% of adults experience chronic LBP at some point). WHO/epidemiological studies document high global prevalence; incidence is less well-defined due to recurrent/intermittent nature. Using prevalence metric appropriate for chronic pain conditions.

Hemophilia A with inhibitor development is a subset (~25-30% of hemophilia A patients). Hemophilia A overall ~1 per 5,000 males. Inhibitor subset = ~0.15 per 100k. Confidence limited by difficulty distinguishing de novo vs acquired inhibitors.

Fecal peritonitis is acute secondary peritonitis from bowel perforation. Estimated incidence ~1.2 per 100k based on bowel perforation rates (1-3 per 100k) and proportion resulting in fecal peritonitis. Limited specific epidemiological studies; confidence capped at 0.55 due to uncertain attribution.

Extremely rare congenital skin condition with no systematic epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on isolated case reports and limited dermatology literature. Confidence very low due to lack of population-based data.
Eccrine nevus is rare benign hamartoma of eccrine sweat glands. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on dermatology case series.
PEODDN is extremely rare variant of eccrine nevus with porokeratotic features. Estimated ~0.1 per 100k based on <100 reported cases in dermatology literature.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major keratinization disorders: psoriasis (~200), ichthyosis (~100), keratosis pilaris (~150), pityriasis rubra pilaris (~50) = ~500 per 100k. Umbrella term with heterogeneous etiologies and incidence.

column9: WHO Global Burden of Disease 2005 report on skin conditions
column14: Dermatitis and eczema are chronic inflammatory conditions; prevalence is the appropriate metric. Global prevalence estimated at 2.45% of population (24,500 per 100k) based on WHO epidemiological data. Includes atopic dermatitis and other forms.

This category includes various specified congenital brain malformations. Birth prevalence of central nervous system anomalies ranges from 1-5 per 1000 live births; specified brain malformations excluding common types estimated at 1.0-1.5 per 100k.
Disseminated non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infections rare, incidence ~0.5-2 per 100k globally. Primarily in immunocompromised patients. WHO surveillance data limited for non-TB mycobacteria.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major benign liver tumors: hemangiomas (5000-10000 per 100k on imaging), adenomas (0.1-0.5 per 100k incidence), focal nodular hyperplasia (common, ~5000 per 100k). Total ~15000 per 100k. Low confidence due to heterogeneity between benign entities with vastly different clinical significance and prevalence.
Rare eyelid coloboma, subset of ocular colobomas. Estimated ~0.3 per 100k births based on limited congenital defect registries.

Corneal fibrosis is a pathological outcome rather than a primary disease entity. It results from various underlying causes (ocular trauma, chemical burns, infection, refractive surgery, etc.). Prevalence estimates ~0.5-1% of population based on ophthalmology clinic surveys and low-income country data where corneal scarring is more common. Cannot establish meaningful incidence without specifying etiology.
Secondary megaloblastic anemia is a rare complication of B12 deficiency, drug toxicity, or GI disorders. Estimated incidence ~0.8 per 100k based on hospital discharge data and hematology literature.
Systemic amyloidosis overall ~0.5-1 per 100k. Nodular (cutaneous) form is subset of localized amyloidosis. Estimated ~0.3 per 100k based on case frequency relative to systemic forms.

Granular corneal dystrophy (GCD) is a rare inherited disorder affecting corneal clarity. Prevalence estimated 1-2 per 100,000 in populations with high gene carrier frequency, but generally <0.5 per 100k globally.

Rare genetic syndrome combining hemiplegia, hemiconvulsion, and epilepsy (HHE). Fewer than 100 cases reported in literature globally. Often autosomal dominant inheritance with PCDH19 or other genetic mutations. Incidence <0.001 per 100k based on case report frequency.

column9: Horton WA (1998). Pediatric Clinics of North America, 45(3), cited in congenital anomaly surveys
column14: Sacrococcygeal teratoma (SCT) is one of the most common congenital tumors. Incidence approximately 1 in 20,000 to 1 in 40,000 live births (3-5 per 100k). Moderate confidence due to limited recent epidemiological studies.

Spastic tetraparesis is a clinical symptom/syndrome rather than a disease entity. It presents in multiple distinct conditions (cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis) with vastly different epidemiologies. Too broad and heterogeneous to map meaningfully.

Recurrent URTIs represent a clinical pattern of repeated upper respiratory infections, primarily affecting children (<12 years) and immunocompromised individuals. Incidence highly variable depending on definition of 'recurrent' (typically 3-8+ episodes per year). Aggregate estimate ~2500 per 100k based on pediatric prevalence of frequent respiratory infections. Confidence limited by vague concept definition.

Laryngeal dysplasia comprises multiple congenital laryngeal abnormalities (webs, stenosis, clefts). Estimated incidence ~2-3 per 100k live births based on pediatric otolaryngology literature. More common than ultra-rare genetic syndromes but data quality remains limited.

Mild depression is a subtype. Using prevalence (~2.5% of population, or 25000 per 100k) and incidence (~300 per 100k for new mild episodes). Significant variation by definition and diagnostic criteria.
Friend leukemia is primarily known as a mouse model disease induced by Friend virus; human epidemiological data not found in medical literature.

Not a well-defined disease entity. Drug substitution is a behavioral descriptor related to substance abuse patterns, not a clinically distinct disease diagnosis that can be meaningfully epidemiologically mapped.

Polydrug abuse (concurrent use of multiple drugs) prevalence estimated at 3% of global adult population (3000 per 100k) based on WHO substance abuse surveys and UNODC data. Incidence harder to define due to behavioral nature.

Unmappable concept: 'Parental alcoholism' refers to a family history risk factor or environmental exposure, not a diagnosable disease entity. This is a social/genetic factor applicable to individuals with affected parents, not an independent health condition with incidence or prevalence in the population.
Splenic hypoplasia (underdeveloped spleen) occurs in various congenital conditions and syndromes. Estimated ~2 per 100k based on pediatric imaging and autopsy studies.

Gender dysphoria reported as prevalence (chronic condition), not incidence. Literature estimates 0.3-0.6% adult prevalence (3,000-6,000 per 100k). Using mid-range estimate of ~4.5% based on recent epidemiological studies.
Symptom descriptor, not a specific disease entity. Can occur in countless conditions (dementia, TBI, stroke, psychiatric disorders, normal aging). Too non-specific to estimate meaningfully.

Atrichia (congenital absence of hair) is an extremely rare autosomal recessive condition. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports, fewer than 100 cases reported in medical literature worldwide.

Basophilia is a laboratory finding (elevated basophil count), not a distinct disease entity. It represents a symptom or manifestation of various underlying conditions including leukemias, myeloproliferative disorders, and reactive conditions. Cannot be meaningfully mapped to a single incidence rate.

column9: WHO Global Asthma Report and regional epidemiological surveys
column14: Chronic allergies measured as prevalence. Global prevalence estimated at 10-20% of population (~15% average) based on WHO epidemiological studies and regional surveys. Using prevalence metric as appropriate for chronic ongoing conditions.

Umbrella term too generic and ill-defined. 'Anemia hemoglobin' is not a specific disease entity - anemia has numerous etiologies (iron deficiency, B12 deficiency, hemolytic, thalassemia, sickle cell, etc.) with vastly different prevalence rates. Cannot meaningfully aggregate or map to incidence.

Adult-onset asthma (asthma developing in age >18 years) accounts for approximately 40-50% of all asthma incidence. Estimated global incidence ~12-15 per 100k person-years. Data quality moderate due to variable case definitions across studies and regions; confidence limited by lack of large-scale prospective cohort studies specifically tracking adult-onset phenotype.

Rare acute vascular event. Upper extremity arterial occlusions are uncommon; brachial artery represents subset of these. Estimated 0.5-1.5 per 100k based on limited vascular surgery epidemiology data. Limited population-based surveillance.

column9: Manfredi S et al. (2006). Epidemiology and management of liver metastases from colorectal cancer. Ann Surg. 244(2):254-259
column14: Colorectal cancer incidence ~40 per 100k globally. Approximately 20% of CRC patients present with metastatic disease at diagnosis, and liver is involved in ~70% of metastatic cases. Estimated ~5-10 per 100k for CRC with liver metastasis. Low confidence due to this being a disease stage rather than a distinct disease entity.
Intractable diarrhea is symptom-based phenotype rather than specific disease. Occurs in ~0.5-2% of diarrheal cases (~50+ per 100k). Concept coherence low; multiple underlying etiologies.

column9: WHO hepatitis surveillance
column14: Cryptogenic hepatitis: idiopathic liver inflammation, estimated ~10 per 100k in some populations.

Hepatic granuloma is a pathological finding (granulomatous inflammation) rather than a specific disease, occurring secondary to TB, fungal infections, sarcoidosis, and other conditions. Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningful incidence.
Recurrent spontaneous or secondary pneumothorax. Estimated ~5 per 100k based on chest surgery and pulmonary registries (subset of all pneumothorax cases).

Sacroiliac arthritis is typically a component of spondyloarthropathies. Reported incidence ~3.5 per 100k person-years; prevalence ~8.5% in population-based studies, higher in ankylosing spondylitis populations.

column9: WHO epidemiological estimates for chronic rhinosinusitis (2005)
column14: Chronic rhinosinusitis is a highly prevalent condition affecting 3-5% of population (3000-5000 per 100k). Reported as prevalence rather than incidence since it's a chronic condition with unclear onset date. Using WHO 2005 prevalence estimates, approximately 3500 per 100k globally.
Type III (mildest form) of Cockayne syndrome, autosomal recessive DNA repair disorder. Estimated <1 per 1,000,000 incidence globally. Very limited case reports.
Recurrent hypersomnia (e.g., Kleine-Levin syndrome). Rare sleep disorder. Estimated ~0.5 per 100k based on sleep medicine case series.

column9: Multi-center trauma registries and neurocritical care outcomes literature
column14: Post-traumatic vegetative state (persistent vegetative state) is a rare outcome of severe traumatic brain injury, with estimated incidence of approximately 15 per 100k person-years. Based on trauma registry and neurocritical care data, though limited epidemiological studies.
Teeth grinding during sleep, chronic condition best measured by prevalence. Affects ~8% of adults (8000 per 100k) based on sleep medicine surveys.
Rare paraneoplastic syndrome associated with anti-Yo antibodies, primarily in gynecologic malignancies. <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency.

column9: Carr AS et al. (2010). Epidemiology of myasthenia gravis in England and Wales. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 81(1):112-115
column14: Aggregate BOTEC estimate for NMJ disorders: myasthenia gravis (~10-20 per 100k incidence), Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (~1-2 per 100k), other NMJ diseases (~5-10 per 100k). Total ~25-30 per 100k. Moderate confidence due to heterogeneity and incomplete epidemiological data for rare variants.

column9: Neonatal HIE prevalence from pediatric neurology literature; adult post-anoxic encephalopathy from cardiac arrest registries
column14: Estimated ~2.5 per 100k based on neonatal HIE incidence (predominant form, ~1-3 per 1000 live births = ~2-3 per 100k total) plus adult post-cardiac arrest encephalopathy cases. Limited epidemiological literature; significant underestimation likely due to neonatal focus in available data.

Brain anoxia-ischemia is a pathophysiological process rather than a specific disease diagnosis. Represents oxygen deprivation consequences in multiple clinical contexts (stroke, hypoxia, cardiac arrest, near-drowning, etc.). No discrete incidence rate; would require specification of underlying cause to estimate meaningfully.

Cerebral anoxia-ischemia is a pathophysiological process/consequence rather than a primary disease diagnosis. It occurs as a complication of multiple underlying conditions (stroke, cardiac arrest, anesthesia complications, etc.) without a discrete incidence rate. Cannot be meaningfully mapped to global incidence.
Rare autosomal chromosomal disorder, estimated <0.001 per 100k births based on cytogenetic studies. Partial trisomy with significant phenotypic variation.

Rare partial chromosomal trisomy affecting long arm of chromosome 12. Incidence estimated <0.01 per 100k live births based on cytogenetics registries. Typically results in developmental delay/intellectual disability. Low confidence due to limited systematic epidemiological data.
Tetrasomy 15q is an extremely rare chromosomal disorder with <50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on cytogenetic registry data.
Rare X-linked developmental disorder predominantly affecting males. Extremely rare <0.01 per 100k male births based on case report frequency in genetics literature.
Extremely rare genetic craniofacial syndrome with eyelid and dental abnormalities, <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports.
Ultra-rare compound syndrome with nephroblastomatosis, fetal ascites, macrosomia and Wilms tumor, <20 cases reported, <0.005 per 100k births.

SCA1 is a rare autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder (note: designator indicates X-linked classification, though SCA1 is primarily autosomal dominant inheritance). Global incidence estimated ~0.2 per 100k based on genetic registries and epidemiological surveys. Limited data availability; confidence capped due to rare disease status and potential nomenclature inconsistency.

X-linked intellectual disability type 3 is a rare monogenic disorder with Mendelian inheritance. Estimated incidence <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports. X-linked intellectual disability as a category affects ~1-2% of males with ID, but individual subtypes are very rare. Limited epidemiological data; confidence reflects rarity and genetic specificity.

column9: WHO Global Burden of Disease 2005
column14: Viral lower respiratory infections (bronchitis, pneumonia) represent significant portion of acute respiratory disease. Estimated ~8500 per 100k annually based on WHO surveillance data for acute lower respiratory infections.
Placental abnormalities (excluding neoplasms) relatively common in pregnancy; estimated ~50 per 100k pregnancies.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Includes both benign (hemangiomas, adenomas) and malignant (hepatocellular carcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma) neoplasms with vastly different incidence rates and clinical significance.

column9: Ophthalmology epidemiology literature
column14: Infectious corneal disease. Bacterial keratitis incidence ~2-4 per 100k in developed countries, higher in contact lens wearers.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), with adenocarcinoma subtype estimation
column14: Lung adenocarcinoma represents ~40% of lung cancers (~35 per 100k), with recurrent cases estimated at ~25% of primary incidence. Limited epidemiological separation of recurrent vs primary adenocarcinoma.
Temporary one-sided weakness (TIA, migraine, seizure, other causes). Estimated ~20 per 100k based on TIA incidence and other causes, though varies widely.

Aggregate category for infections in elderly population (>65 years). Highly variable by infection type and setting. Rough BOTEC estimate ~5000 per 100k elderly per year based on hospitalization rates.

S. aureus accounts for 10-15% of bacterial pneumonias. Global bacterial pneumonia incidence ~20-30 per 100k; S. aureus subset estimated at 3.5 per 100k. Based on hospital surveillance and pneumonia epidemiology studies.

Umbrella term for all vascular aneurysms (abdominal aortic, cerebral, etc.). Aggregate estimate ~8 per 100k combining AAA (~1.5), cerebral aneurysms (~2-3), thoracic (~1), peripheral (~0.5-1). Moderate confidence due to heterogeneity.

column9: UNODC World Drug Report 2005
column14: Cocaine addiction has both incidence (new users) ~850 per 100k and prevalence (active users) ~1200 per 100k globally. Data from UNODC 2005 and WHO estimates, though substance abuse epidemiology has significant uncertainty.

Hypoglycemic episodes from insulin treatment occur in approximately 150-200 per 100k diabetic patient-years (roughly 2-3 episodes per diabetic per year among ~80 million diabetics). Incidence calculated as complication rate rather than primary disease incidence.

Neonatal intestinal obstruction incidence ~1-3 per 1000 live births (~100-300 per 100k births). Accounting for live births globally ~130 million/year, estimated incidence ~25 per 100k general population.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) represents 15-20% of breast cancer diagnoses. Global breast cancer incidence ~43 per 100k (2005 data). DCIS incidence estimated at 6-8 per 100k population. Based on cancer registry data.

Retinal toxicity (drug-induced or chemical) incidence estimated at ~2.5 per 100k based on pharmaceutical adverse event reporting for agents like chloroquine, tamoxifen, and ethambutol. Highly dependent on drug exposure patterns.

column9: WHO Global Asthma Report 2004
column14: Chronic asthma reported as prevalence (~3.5% global population, ~3,500 per 100k). WHO Global Asthma Report (2004-2005) indicates chronic asthma prevalence varies by region from 1-10%.

Specific psychogenic subtype of circadian rhythm disorder. Circadian rhythm disorders affect ~1-3% of adults, but this psychogenic variant is substantially rarer. Insufficient epidemiological data for precise incidence.

Tetanilla is not a standard, well-defined medical condition in major epidemiological databases or medical literature. May be a regional or archaic term, or a potential misspelling. Unmappable due to lack of standardized definition and no verifiable epidemiological data.
Progressive muscular atrophy (lower motor neuron variant of ALS), incidence ~0.4 per 100k, prevalence ~5 per 100k. Limited epidemiological registries.

column9: Carcinoid/neuroendocrine tumor registries and pathology databases
column14: Enterochromaffin cell hyperplasia is a histopathological finding most commonly associated with carcinoid syndrome and neuroendocrine tumors. Estimated incidence ~1.2 per 100k based on carcinoid tumor registries and autopsy studies. Confidence moderate-low due to being a histological rather than clinical diagnosis with limited epidemiological surveillance.

Umbrella term describing stage/spread descriptor rather than distinct disease. Cannot estimate meaningfully - 'metastatic renal carcinoma' is a clinical presentation of renal cancer rather than separable disease entity. Incidence would be subset of renal cancer incidence but proportion varies by presentation timing.

Nephrotoxic serum nephritis is a specific type of acute glomerulonephritis with autoimmune etiology. Estimated ~0.8 per 100k based on post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis epidemiology and case reports, though exact incidence data is limited.

Corneal thinning is often a manifestation of keratoconus and other corneal ectasias rather than a primary disease. Prevalence estimated at <0.5 per 100k based on ophthalmology literature. Poor epidemiological data; represents symptom cluster rather than specific disease entity.
Chronic condition measured by prevalence. Global prevalence ~3.5% of adult female population (35 per 1000) based on epidemiological surveys. Significant geographic and age-related variation.
Mast cell aggregation is a pathological process rather than a distinct disease entity. Related to mastocytosis conditions (incidence ~0.5-2 per 100k). Concept coherence low; definition vague.
Granulomatous form of IBD (likely Crohn's disease with granuloma), estimated incidence ~8-9 per 100k based on IBD epidemiological registries.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) global incidence ~10-15 per 100k with high geographic variation. Stage IV represents advanced disease at diagnosis (~40-60% of cases). Estimated stage IV incidence ~8 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 data with regional variation from <1 per 100k (low-incidence regions) to >25 per 100k (high-incidence regions like East Asia).
Acute invasive meningococcal disease with bacteremia. Global incidence approximately 2-3 per 100k based on WHO epidemiological surveillance data and regional registries (varies widely by region).

Nevus cell nevus is a benign melanocytic lesion characterized histologically by nests of nevus cells. This is a common cutaneous finding; prevalence estimated at 15-25% of population based on dermatological surveys. Specific subtype prevalence poorly defined in epidemiological literature.

Paratubal cysts are benign gynecological findings discovered on imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI), often asymptomatic. Prevalence estimated at 1-2% of women (1500 per 100k) based on imaging studies, though true epidemiology depends on population screening rates.
MRSA pneumonia incidence estimated at ~3-4 per 100k, though increasing over time period. Data from CDC and hospital registries from early 2000s.

column9: Lin AE et al. (2000). Heterotaxy: associated conditions and hospital-based prevalence in newborns. Genet Med. 2(3):157-172
column14: Situs ambiguous (visceral heterotaxy) with abnormal organ arrangement. Estimated ~1.5 per 100k births based on congenital malformation registries.
Severe skin condition with epidermal death (TEN, SJS, severe burns). Estimated ~3 per 100k based on TEN/SJS incidence and burn registries.

column13: Anemia, secondary to chronic kidney disease
column14: Uremic anemia is a secondary condition of chronic kidney disease/dialysis. Estimated prevalence ~240 per 100k based on ESRD prevalence (~600 per million or 60 per 100k)  ~40% anemia rate. Reported as prevalence since this is a chronic condition associated with ESRD, not a new onset disease. Confidence limited by regional variation in CKD prevalence and management.

Renoprival hypertension develops after unilateral nephrectomy or severe unilateral renal disease. Estimated incidence ~10-20% of nephrectomy patients (~1-2 per 1000 person-years in at-risk population). Limited epidemiological data; incidence depends on renal pathology and surgical rates. Confidence limited by lack of population-based surveillance data.

column9: Pediatric disease registry data (various countries)
column14: Rectosigmoid aganglionosis is the most common form of Hirschsprung disease, affecting ~1-2 per 100k live births. Incidence based on pediatric disease registries.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major glucose metabolism disorders: Type 2 diabetes incidence (~15 per 100k), Type 1 diabetes incidence (~3 per 100k), gestational diabetes (~5 per 100k), prediabetes/impaired fasting glucose (~8000 per 100k when including milder metabolic dysregulation), other glucose disorders (~500 per 100k). Heterogeneous umbrella term with significant overlap between categories and varying clinical significance. Confidence capped at 0.22 due to aggregation of disparate conditions.
Hypertrophic/morbid obesity (BMI >40) affects ~5-10% of obese populations. Global obesity incidence ~5000+ per 100k; severe form estimated ~500 per 100k. Concept coherence moderate.

Advanced cirrhosis subset of all cirrhosis cases. Global cirrhosis incidence ~8-10 per 100k (from HBV/HCV/alcohol), with prevalence ~120 per 100k. Advanced cirrhosis represents approximately 20-30% of all cirrhosis cases.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate summing major organic acid metabolism disorders: propionic acidemia (~1.5), methylmalonic aciduria (~2.0), isovaleric acidemia (~1.2), glutaric aciduria (~1.5), other OAM disorders (~2.3) = ~8.5 per 100k births. Umbrella term with heterogeneous subtypes and significant diagnostic overlap; low confidence reflects composite nature and varying severity.

Persistent infection is a process descriptor rather than a specific disease entity. Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully - includes persistent viral infections (HIV, HBV, HCV), bacterial infections (TB, syphilis), and parasitic infections with vastly different epidemiologies and clinical significance.

Non-specific descriptor, not a disease entity. Could refer to cysts in any organ (kidney, liver, ovary, etc.) with vastly different incidence rates and clinical significance. Too vague to estimate meaningfully.
Polymorphous low-grade adenocarcinoma (PLGA) is a rare salivary gland malignancy, accounts for <2% of salivary tumors. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on tumor registry data.

column9: Thymic malignancy hospital registries and WHO Classification of Tumours
column14: Type AB thymoma is the most common histological subtype (~40% of all thymomas). Global thymoma incidence ~0.3 per 100k; Type AB estimated at ~40% = 0.12 per 100k. Based on WHO histological classification and hospital registry data.
Extremely rare soft tissue neoplasm, <0.05 per 100k based on limited case reports, no systematic epidemiological data.
Localized candidiasis (oral, vaginal, skin) relatively common fungal infection; estimated ~150 per 100k person-years globally.

Scotopic sensitivity (visual sensitivity in dim light) is a symptom/condition associated with retinal dystrophies and night blindness. Not a distinct disease. Estimated prevalence based on night blindness prevalence (night blindness affects 0.5% of adults globally from various causes).

column9: Holick MF et al. (2005). Vitamin D and skin physiology: a D-lightful story. J Bone Miner Res. 22(Suppl 2):V28-V33
column14: Vitamin D3 deficiency is measured as prevalence (existing cases), not incidence. Global estimates indicate 25-50% of population has insufficient vitamin D levels. Using conservative prevalence estimate of 28% (28,000 per 100k). Measurement varies by 25(OH)D threshold definition.
Extremely rare inherited keratoderma subtype, <0.01 per 100k based on case reports. Limited epidemiological data available.
Recurrent cold sores, highly common. Estimated ~2000 per 100k (2%) experience recurrent episodes annually based on HSV-1 seroprevalence and reactivation rates.
