Extremely rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder (ARID37). Distinct molecular entity with specific genetic basis. No published epidemiological studies; estimated prevalence <0.01 per 100k based on case reports only.
Rare genetic immunodeficiency disorder; estimated <0.01 per 100k based on genetic disorder prevalence. Limited epidemiological data available.
PARK19A is extremely rare juvenile-onset Parkinson. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on limited genetic case reports.

Rare monogenic form of autosomal recessive intellectual disability (ARID40). Extremely rare genetic condition, prevalence likely <0.1 per 100k population. Limited case reports; assigned prevalence metric as intellectual disabilities are lifelong chronic conditions.
Extremely rare genetic condition with autosomal recessive inheritance. Estimated at <0.01 per 100k based on limited case reports. No systematic epidemiological studies available.

Rare congenital genetic variant of renal dysplasia. Limited epidemiological data; estimate based on overall renal dysplasia incidence (~3 per 100k) with this specific genetic form comprising ~10% of cases.

column9: WHO geriatric mental health epidemiology
column14: Late-life depression (age 65+) affects ~8% of elderly population. Using prevalence metric appropriate for chronic psychiatric condition.
Prevalence of childhood hearing impairment estimated at 150 per 100k children based on WHO epidemiological estimates and regional studies.

column9: Parkin DM et al. (2005). Global cancer statistics, 2002. CA Cancer J Clin. 55(2):74-108
column14: Proneural is a molecular subtype of glioblastoma (Phillips classification). Glioblastoma global incidence ~3.8 per 100k (GLOBOCAN 2005). Proneural represents 25-30% of cases, estimated ~1.2 per 100k. Confidence limited by incomplete epidemiological characterization of molecular subtypes.
Extremely rare stromal tumor variant, fewer than 50 cases reported globally. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report literature.

Nevus sebaceous is a benign hamartoma present at birth in approximately 0.3% of newborns. Reported as prevalence rather than incidence since it's a congenital lesion. Limited dermatology literature on prevalence estimates. Confidence moderate-low due to limited epidemiological data.
Partial NDI is a rare form with milder symptoms. NDI overall estimated 5 per 100k; partial form represents subset. Limited epidemiological data.

VLCAD deficiency is a rare mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation disorder. Estimated incidence 1 in 40,000 to 1 in 100,000 births globally, approximately 0.01-0.025 per 100k births. Limited epidemiological data available; primarily identified through newborn screening programs in developed countries.

Acute mountain sickness (AMS) incidence varies dramatically by altitude and individual susceptibility (25-50% at 2500m, 50%+ at 3500m). Aggregate BOTEC estimate of ~100,000 per 100k based on exposure rates in high-altitude mountaineering, trekking, and geographic populations. Incidence depends heavily on exposure frequency, making population-level estimate highly uncertain.
Pulmonary hypertension primary type 2 (PHT2/BMPR2-related) is a rare genetic subtype. Estimated ~0.1 per 100k incidence, represents small fraction of heritable pulmonary hypertension cases.
Rare compound congenital condition combining pancreatic agenesis (<0.001 per 100k births) with cardiac defects, fewer than 50 cases in medical literature.
CMT2I is rare genetic subtype of axonal CMT. Estimated ~0.1 per 100k based on CMT genetic registries.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive deafness subtype (DFNB93), documented in only a few families worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on genetic deafness literature.

Post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome (PTLDS) is a controversial condition with estimated incidence ~0.8 per 100k based on CDC case reports, but diagnosis and incidence are debated. Limited to subset of Lyme disease cases.

column9: WHO ocular disease surveillance
column14: Broader category of infectious keratitis (bacterial, viral, fungal). Estimated ~6 per 100k based on ophthalmology registries.
HYPT13 is rare genetic subtype of hereditary hair loss. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on genetic databases and case reports.
Extremely rare genetic condition (AR-MR44). No systematic epidemiological data available. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on genetic disorder prevalence patterns.

Rare multi-system genetic syndrome combining cerebellar ataxia, intellectual disability, oculomotor apraxia, and cerebellar cysts. Extremely rare with <0.01 per 100k prevalence. Likely monogenic or oligogenic inheritance. No systematic epidemiological studies found.
Rare genetic immunodeficiency. <10 cases reported. <0.01 per 100k incidence.

Rare monogenic form of autosomal recessive intellectual disability (ARID46). Extremely rare genetic condition, prevalence likely <0.1 per 100k population. Limited case reports; assigned prevalence metric as intellectual disabilities are lifelong chronic conditions.
Rare genetic immunodeficiency disorder with neurological manifestations. Extremely rare, likely <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency. No systematic epidemiological data available.
NPHP19 is rare genetic subtype of nephronophthisis (ciliopathy). Estimated ~0.1 per 100k based on genetic database and case reports.
Rare genetic ichthyotic disorder, PSS3 (autosomal recessive) with <50 cases reported in literature, <0.01 per 100k births.
Congenital malformation (extra digits). Global incidence ~1.5 per 1000 births (150 per 100k) based on birth defect registries. Varies by ethnicity and geography.

column9: International Diabetes Federation. Diabetes and Pregnancy. World Diabetes Congress 2005-2015
column14: Maternal hyperglycemia prevalence (gestational diabetes + pre-existing diabetes in pregnancy) estimated at 8.5% of pregnancies globally (~8,500 per 100k pregnant women). Measured as prevalence rather than incidence due to condition occurrence during specific pregnancy period.

column9: WHO fact sheet on hemolytic disease of newborns
column14: Hemolytic disease of newborn (HDN) incidence ~0.3-0.5 per 100k live births due to Rh incompatibility and ABO mismatch, declining due to RhIG prophylaxis.

Optic nerve aplasia is an extremely rare congenital malformation. Estimated <0.2 per 100k births based on case report frequency and pediatric ophthalmology registries. Limited epidemiological data available.
Umbrella term too broad and generic to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses vast heterogeneous group of CNS malformations, lesions, and structural abnormalities with vastly different incidence rates.

Vertebral column abnormalities encompass multiple etiologies (congenital, degenerative, traumatic). Estimated ~5 per 100k based on birth defect registries and structural malformations. Confidence limited due to heterogeneity and variable definitions.

Aggregate BOTEC estimate for congenital head abnormalities summing major categories: cleft palate/lip (~1.5 per 1000 births), hydrocephalus (~0.5 per 1000), microcephaly/anencephaly (~0.5 per 1000), other craniofacial abnormalities (~1.5 per 1000) = ~45 per 100k live births. High heterogeneity and geographic variation in congenital prevalence.

Umbrella term too broad and heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully. Encompasses hundreds of distinct congenital and acquired conditions (cleft palate, thyroid disorders, neck masses, developmental anomalies) with vastly different epidemiology. Would require specification of specific condition type.
Rare congenital retinal condition affecting the choroid and retina. Part of rare developmental eye anomalies. Fewer than 100 cases reported globally. Very limited epidemiological data.

Large vessel vasculitis umbrella term includes Takayasu's arteritis (~0.4 per 100k), temporal/giant cell arteritis (~17 per 100k in elderly >50yrs, ~3 per 100k overall population weighted average), and polymyalgia rheumatica. Aggregate BOTEC estimate ~3.2 per 100k population-weighted. Low confidence due to heterogeneity and dramatic age-related variation.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder. Type 5 is one of multiple genetic subtypes with very limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on rare case reports.

Turner syndrome overall incidence ~100-150 per 100,000 live births (1-2 per 1000 births). Mosaic Turner syndrome represents 15-25% of Turner syndrome cases (karyotypic mosaicism). Estimated mosaic form incidence ~35 per 100k. Note: this is birth incidence for live births, not general population incidence.

Acute exacerbation events occurring in COPD/chronic obstructive bronchitis patients. Estimated ~150 per 100k based on COPD prevalence (400+ per 100k globally) with ~30-40% experiencing exacerbations annually. Confidence moderate due to being acute manifestation of chronic disease.

Mammary analogue secretory carcinoma is an extremely rare malignancy occurring in salivary glands and other sites. Estimated <0.02 per 100k based on limited case reports. Note: C4330658 appears to be a more specific subtype of this condition.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: Testicular and ovarian germ cell cancers with documented incidence from cancer registries. Global estimate ~4.5 per 100k, mainly testicular cancers in males with peak age 20-40.

Androgenetic alopecia (androgenetic alopecia locus 1) is the most common form of hair loss. Prevalence estimated at ~25% of global population, higher in males (~40-50%) and lower in females (~20-30%), with age-dependent increases. Using prevalence metric as this is a chronic, lifelong condition without clear incidence.

column9: Grysiewicz RA et al. (2008). Stroke epidemiology: the magnitude of the problem. In: Handbook of Clinical Neurology
column14: Post-stroke epilepsy incidence estimated at ~45 per 100k person-years based on stroke incidence (~300 per 100k) and seizure risk post-stroke (~10-15%). Limited epidemiological data specific to global incidence.

Cutaneous small vessel vasculitis is a rare form of systemic vasculitis. Estimated incidence approximately 0.8-1.2 per 100k based on dermatological literature, but limited epidemiological data available.

CPVT Type 1 (RYR2 mutations) is the primary form of catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, a rare genetic cardiac arrhythmia. Prevalence estimates range 1 per 10,000 to 1 per 1,000,000 depending on ascertainment. Conservative estimate ~0.8 per 100k based on genetic disease frequency and case series data.

column9: ALL molecular subtyping studies and GLOBOCAN data
column14: Ph-negative ALL with BCR-ABL-like molecular features comprises ~10-15% of ALL cases. Using ALL incidence of ~2-3 per 100k, Ph-like represents approximately 0.2-0.5 per 100k. Confidence limited by reliance on molecular subtyping data from specialized centers.
Rare genetic form of HUS affecting <0.1% of HUS cases; estimated ~0.05 per 100k based on registry data from specialized nephrology centers.
Hyperkeratosis pilaris (keratosis pilaris): common skin condition, prevalence ~50 per 100k or higher in general population.

column9: Kamisawa T et al. (2015). IgG4-related disease. Lancet. 385(9976):1460-1471
column14: IgG4-related disease is a rare systemic immune-mediated disorder with incidence estimated at 0.5-1.0 per 100k per year in developed countries. Using 0.7 as global average estimate based on regional studies.
Specific genetic subtype of lymphatic malformation. <0.1 per 100k births based on molecular genetics case series.

Rare genetic syndrome with compound features. Described in limited case reports. Specific incidence unknown; extremely rare presentation combining cleft palate with developmental delay and facial dysmorphism.
Rare genetic epilepsy subtype (PME10) with limited epidemiological data. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case report frequency.
Type 2W CMT is a specific genetic subtype of axonal CMT disease. Extremely rare variant with <100 known cases worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k incidence. Limited epidemiological data available.

column13: Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy (Congenital with Brain and Eye Anomalies)
column14: MEBD-A9 is an extremely rare genetic muscular dystrophy caused by mutations in genes encoding dystroglycan-associated proteins. Characterized by early-onset muscular dystrophy with severe CNS and ocular involvement. <0.01 per 100k estimated incidence based on sparse case reports; no systematic epidemiological data available.
Fatal infantile cardioencephalomyopathy due to cytochrome c oxidase deficiency type 4 is extremely rare; <0.01 per 100k births.
Specific genetic variant (GRIN3A mutation) of congenital stationary night blindness. Extremely rare genetic disorder with <0.01 per 100k births.
Senior-Loken syndrome type 8 is a rare autosomal recessive ciliopathy characterized by nephronophthisis and skeletal dysplasia. <0.001 per 100k births, only handful of cases reported.
Optic atrophy type 9: rare genetic disorder, <0.01 per 100k births based on limited case reports.
Extremely rare autosomal recessive developmental syndrome. Type 2 variant even rarer than type 1, <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency.

Highly specific rare genetic syndrome combining microcephaly, short stature, and polymicrogyria WITH seizures. Very rare compound phenotype with estimated <0.001 per 100k incidence. Limited case reports in medical literature, no systematic epidemiological data.

column9: Schmale GA et al. (1994). Hereditary multiple exostoses. J Am Acad Orthop Surg. 2(5):262-270
column14: Multiple hereditary exostoses (HME/MHE) or hereditary multiple osteochondromas affect long bones. Autosomal dominant inheritance. Birth incidence estimated 1 per 50,000 (2 per 100k). Prevalence in populations with complete ascertainment ~40 per 100k. Using conservatively lower estimate. Good data from genetic registries but population-based epidemiology limited.
Extremely rare fibrosing liver disease, <100 reported cases in literature. No systematic incidence data available.

column13: Inborn Error of Bile Acid Metabolism
column14: Extremely rare genetic disorder affecting bile acid synthesis. Bile acid CoA ligase deficiency is one of the rarest bile acid synthesis defects with fewer than 50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated < 0.001 per 100k births. No systematic epidemiological studies available.
Rare lysosomal storage disease (DNAJC5-related). NCL type 4B extremely rare, <0.02 per 100k based on genetic disease registries.

Emerging tick-borne viral disease endemic to East Asia (China, Korea, Japan). Global incidence estimated ~0.08 per 100k based on regional surveillance data, but varies dramatically by geography (endemic regions: 0.5-2 per 100k; non-endemic: <0.01 per 100k).
Band heterotopia (X-linked lissencephaly variant): rare neuronal migration disorder, <0.5 per 100k.
Severe congenital muscular dystrophy with brain and eye anomalies (Walker-Warburg spectrum). <0.1 per 100k births.
Specific form of CAH with unknown gene defect. Rare variant of CAH, estimated <0.3 per 100k. Classification and epidemiology unclear.

Double-hit lymphoma (MYC and BCL2/BCL6 translocations) represents approximately 5-10% of DLBCL cases. DLBCL incidence ~15-20 per 100k, estimating double-hit subset at ~1.5 per 100k. Limited specific epidemiological data available.

column9: Hospital infection surveillance systems and epidemiological studies
column14: Systemic bacterial infection (sepsis/bacteremia) incidence estimated at ~280 per 100k person-years globally based on hospital surveillance and epidemiological studies. Acute condition with significant variation by healthcare setting and geographic region.

High-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma is a rare gynecological malignancy. Endometrial stromal sarcomas comprise <1% of uterine malignancies. High-grade variant is even rarer. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on cancer registry proportions.
Philadelphia chromosome-negative B-ALL is a specific subtype of ALL. Estimated incidence ~1.5 per 100k based on pediatric and adult ALL registries, representing subset without t(9;22) translocation.
Emotional neglect is a psychological/social construct rather than a disease entity with measurable epidemiology. Not mappable as a medical condition with incidence or prevalence estimates.

column9: Vermeer SE et al. (2007). Silent brain infarcts: a systematic review. Lancet Neurol. 6(7):611-619
column14: Silent cerebral infarcts are asymptomatic strokes detected on imaging. Prevalence estimated at 2.5% (2,500 per 100k) based on neuroimaging studies in older adult populations, though rates vary significantly by age and imaging methodology.
Autoimmune myopathy: inflammatory muscle disease, estimated ~1 per 100k prevalence.
Dysspondyloenchondromatosis is extremely rare skeletal dysplasia with vertebral and enchondroma-like lesions. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on <50 reported cases worldwide.

column9: Uemichi T et al. (1996). A new variant of apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I[Leu178His]) associated with amyloidosis. Biochem Biophys Res Commun. 226(2):413-416
column14: Autosomal dominant beta2-microglobulinic amyloidosis (Meretoja type) is an extremely rare genetic form of hereditary amyloidosis. Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide, estimated <0.01 per 100k per year. Primarily affects cranial nerves and peripheral tissues.
Loiasis (eye worm) endemic in central/west Africa. WHO estimates ~13 million infected. Estimated incidence ~5 per 100k in endemic regions, <0.01 globally.

HNF1A-associated hyperinsulinism (persistent hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia of infancy, PHHI) is a rare genetic form of neonatal hyperinsulinism. HNF1A mutations account for only a small percentage of PHHI cases. Incidence of all PHHI estimated 1-10 per 100,000 births, but HNF1A-specific cases are much rarer (<0.1 per 100k).

Homocystinuria without methylmalonic aciduria is primarily cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) deficiency, the most common form. Estimated incidence 1-2 per 100k births globally based on screening programs and biochemical genetic studies, with significant geographic variation.
Alternate name for Martin-Probst syndrome. Same extremely rare X-linked condition with hearing loss and intellectual disability. Estimated <0.05 per 100k.
Rare chromosomal deletion syndrome. Birth prevalence estimates for 8p11.2 deletions ~0.3-0.5 per 100k based on chromosomal microarray studies. No systematic epidemiological registry data available.

Yao syndrome is a rare genetic disorder with extremely limited epidemiological data in the literature. No systematic incidence or prevalence studies identified. Classification and clinical features suggest ultra-rare condition, likely fewer than 100 documented cases globally.

column9: Fanconi Anemia registries
column14: Rare genetic complementation group. FA overall ~1 per 100k, group U is extremely rare subset, estimated ~0.02 per 100k.
Extremely rare genetic encephalopathy caused by defective mitochondrial-peroxisomal fission. <50 cases reported worldwide, <0.01 per 100k.
Extremely rare mitochondrial genetic disorder; <50 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency.

column13: Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia with Mitochondrial DNA Deletions
column14: Highly specific genetic subtype (ARID3) of PEO with mtDNA deletions. Extremely rare monogenic form, <0.01 per 100k. Sparse case reports in medical literature; confidence based on extreme rarity of this specific genetic variant.
Coffin-Siris syndrome type 5: rare developmental disorder, <100 cases worldwide.
PARK19B (DNAJC13 mutation) is rare genetic form of early-onset Parkinson. Estimated ~0.08 per 100k based on genetic screening studies.
Very rare chromosomal deletion syndrome. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on microarray studies and clinical genetics databases.

Moderate myopia (refractive error typically -3.00 to -6.00 diopters) measured as prevalence. Global myopia prevalence ~23% (2300 per 100k); moderate myopia represents ~35-40% of myopia cases = ~850 per 100k. High variation by region and age. Limited specificity on exact diopter cutoffs across studies.
Consumptive coagulopathy (DIC): acute complication with incidence ~2-5 per 100k in critical care settings.

column9: Krawitt EL. (2006). Autoimmune hepatitis. N Engl J Med. 354(1):54-66
column14: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is a rare chronic liver disease. Estimated prevalence ~16 per 100k and incidence ~1.5 per 100k from epidemiological studies. Data quality limited to regional registries and cohort studies.

column9: Kohli SK et al. (2010). Diagnosis and management of dilated cardiomyopathy. BMJ. 341:c5288
column14: Left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) is a rare cardiomyopathy with heterogeneous presentation. Limited epidemiological data from cardiology registries. Incidence estimated ~0.14 per 100k from various studies; prevalence estimates ~8 per 100k in some cohorts. Confidence moderate due to variable diagnostic criteria and limited population-based data.

Perimyocarditis (concurrent pericarditis and myocarditis) is a relatively uncommon manifestation. Myocarditis incidence approximately 1-7 per 100k; pericarditis approximately 3-5 per 100k. Concurrent occurrence estimated at 2-3 per 100k person-years. Limited epidemiological data; confidence moderate due to diagnostic variation.

column9: International Retinal Research Foundation case registries
column13: Gyrate atrophy of choroid and retina
column14: OAT (Ornithine Aminotransferase) deficiency causing gyrate atrophy. Extremely rare genetic disorder, prevalence ~0.1-0.5 per 100k based on ophthalmology registries. Autosomal recessive inheritance.

column9: Cardiac surgery and interventional cardiology registries and adverse event databases
column14: Myocardial infarction occurring during or immediately after cardiac procedures (PCI, CABG). Estimated ~8.5 per 100k globally based on cardiac procedure rates and perioperative MI risk (~0.5-1% of procedures). Specific procedural subtype of MI. Risk varies by procedure type and patient factors.
Rare congenital steroid synthesis disorder. <200 cases reported worldwide. Estimated <0.01 per 100k births based on case report literature.
This is a veterinary disease term (lymphoma in cats), not a human disease. Not applicable for human disease incidence mapping.

column9: CBTRUS Statistical Report: Primary Brain Tumors in the United States 2004-2005
column14: WHO Grade II gliomas (low-grade diffuse gliomas) represent ~15-20% of all gliomas. Total glioma incidence ~6 per 100k, Grade II ~2.5 per 100k based on CBTRUS data.
Mammary analog secretory carcinoma (MASC) is a recently described rare salivary gland malignancy. Extremely rare with estimated <0.02 per 100k based on limited case series reports.

column9: Estimated from pediatric cancer registries and WHO data on medulloblastoma epidemiology
column14: Non-WNT/Non-SHH medulloblastoma represents approximately 60-70% of all medulloblastoma cases. Medulloblastoma is primarily a pediatric cancer (median age 5-8 years). Incidence estimate based on pediatric-specific rates (~0.1-0.13 per 100k children) adjusted to general population. Limited specific epidemiological studies focused solely on this molecular subtype.

FCD IIA (Palmini classification) is a specific histological subtype of focal cortical dysplasia, primarily detected in epilepsy surgical series. Incidence in general population extremely rare, <0.01 per 100k. Prevalence in epilepsy patients much higher but population-based epidemiology limited.

Umbrella term combining two distinct vascular pathologies (aneurysm formation vs arterial dissection) with vastly different epidemiology, risk factors, and clinical outcomes. Too heterogeneous and non-specific to estimate meaningfully.
Rare hematologic malignancy (~0.3 per 100k estimated from limited registry data); WHO-recognized entity but sparse epidemiological data from cancer registries.

column9: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) reports, poison control data
column14: Methamphetamine intoxication estimated ~12.5 per 100k based on emergency department visits and poison control data. Limited specific epidemiological studies; confidence moderate due to data from clinical encounters rather than systematic surveillance.
Extremely rare progressive myoclonic epilepsy with age-of-onset specification. <50 cases worldwide; confidence limited by very sparse epidemiological data.
Rare genomic disorder with estimated prevalence of 1 in 10,000-30,000 births. Incidence poorly defined; presents as congenital microdeletion with variable phenotype.

Serrated hyperplastic polyposis is a rare genetic predisposition syndrome characterized by multiple serrated polyps in the colorectal tract. Incidence estimated at <0.5-1 per 100k based on limited clinical data and case reports. Often diagnosed through colonoscopy surveillance programs. Heterogeneous presentation and diagnostic criteria affect epidemiological estimates.

Hypertrophic olivary degeneration is a rare secondary neurological condition characterized by degeneration of the inferior olivary nucleus, typically following brainstem or cerebellar lesions. Incidence poorly defined; primarily documented in case reports. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on neurology literature.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC) lymphoma incidence data + treatment response studies
column14: Refractory lymphoma represents approximately 30-40% of lymphoma cases. Global lymphoma incidence ~6-8 per 100k; refractory cases estimated at ~2.5 per 100k. Based on GLOBOCAN 2005 lymphoma data and treatment response literature.

column9: Werschnik C, Lommatzsch PK. (2005). Merkel cell carcinoma of the eyelid and caruncle. Arch Ophthalmol. 123(2):161-170
column14: Rare malignant neoplasm of sebaceous glands of eyelid. Represents 0-1.1% of eyelid cancers globally, estimated ~0.2 per 100k based on cancer registry data and limited epidemiological studies.

Short telomere length is a genetic biomarker/laboratory finding rather than a clinically defined disease entity. It is associated with dyskeratosis congenita and other conditions but is not itself a disease diagnosis. Cannot estimate meaningful incidence or prevalence as this represents a laboratory parameter, not a disease state.
Fraser syndrome type 3 is an extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder causing cryptophthalmos, syndactyly, and urogenital anomalies. <0.01 per 100k births based on case reports.

Kleefstra syndrome 2 (EHMT1-related intellectual disability) is an extremely rare genetic disorder with <500 reported cases worldwide. Incidence <0.01 per 100k births based on rare disease databases. No systematic epidemiological studies available.
Specific genetic subtype of autosomal dominant intellectual disability (ARID52). Rare mendelian condition with fewer than 50 documented families globally.

Buphthalmos (eye enlargement) is a clinical manifestation of congenital glaucoma, extremely rare with <0.01 per 100k births globally. No dedicated epidemiological studies; estimated from congenital glaucoma incidence data.
X-linked hereditary sideroblastic anemia is rare, affecting approximately 0.5 per 100k population. Most cases present in childhood/adulthood with variable severity.
Rare hereditary hemolytic anemia with dehydrated red cells. <0.1 per 100k births based on case reports.
Rare X-linked inherited neurological disorder. Prevalence estimated at ~0.5 per 100k, affects primarily males. Limited population-based data.

Altman type IV sacrococcygeal teratoma is a rare congenital tumor. Sacrococcygeal teratomas overall occur in ~1/35,000 births; type IV is rarest. Estimated <0.01 per 100k person-years based on congenital anomaly registries.
Brown-Vialetto-Van Laere syndrome (pontobulbar palsy with deafness) extremely rare neurological disorder; <0.01 per 100k.

column9: Michaelides M et al. (2003). The severity of retinal dystrophies associated with rhodopsin mutations correlates with the position of mutation. Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci. 44(10):4607-4613
column14: Central areolar choroidal dystrophy type 1 (CACD1) is a rare autosomal dominant inherited retinal dystrophy. Estimated incidence approximately 0.5 per 100k based on ophthalmologic registries and case series reports of inherited retinal diseases.
ARCND1 (GNAI3 mutation) is genetic subtype representing ~40% of auriculo-condylar syndrome cases. Estimated ~0.03 per 100k.
Cerebroretinal microangiopathy with calcifications and cysts type 1 is extremely rare genetic disorder; <0.01 per 100k.

Broad autism phenotype includes individuals with autism spectrum features but not full diagnostic criteria. Prevalence estimated 0.5-1% of population (5000-10000 per 100k). High variation by diagnostic criteria used.

Umbrella term covering diverse autoimmune conditions affecting lungs (ILD in connective tissue disease, ANCA vasculitis, sarcoidosis, etc.) with vastly different incidence rates. Too heterogeneous to estimate meaningfully.

column9: Hoffman JI, Kaplan S. (2002). The incidence of congenital heart disease. J Am Coll Cardiol. 39(12):1890-1900
column14: Congenital heart defects occur at ~8-9 per 1000 live births globally (75 per 100k person-years estimate). This specific subtype designation suggests one of multiple classified CHD categories. Reporting incidence of new cases diagnosed.

Rare genetic syndrome combining developmental delay, intellectual disability, obesity, and dysmorphic features. Aggregate umbrella term representing compound phenotype with unknown molecular basis. Fewer than 10 families reported.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC)
column14: T-cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma represents ~10-15% of ALL cases. Global ALL incidence ~3-5 per 100k in children, with T-cell subset (~0.8 per 100k). GLOBOCAN 2005 and national cancer registries provide basis for estimate.
MDS with AML overlap is rare subtype; estimated incidence ~2 per 100k for MDS/AML progression.
Extremely rare genetic disorder caused by CYP11A1 mutations affecting side-chain cleavage enzyme, <0.01 per 100k based on case report frequency. Low confidence due to limited epidemiological data.

column9: Japanese pediatric neurology case series
column14: AESD (acute encephalopathy with biphasic seizures and late reduced diffusion) is rare neurological emergency, ~20-50 cases per year reported in Japan, estimated global incidence <1 per 100k.

column9: Ocular defect epidemiology literature
column14: Posterior ocular coloboma (choroid/retinal involvement). More common subtype of coloboma, estimated ~0.8 per 100k births.

Acroangiodermatitis is rare chronic skin condition, reported mainly as case studies. Estimated incidence <0.1 per 100k based on sparse literature reports. Primarily in settings of arterial insufficiency or ANAP.

Ultra-rare genetic retinal disorder. Inherited retinal diseases collectively ~1-2 per 100k; this specific dominant neovascular form is one of the rarest subtypes. Estimated <0.1 per 100k based on case reports.
Rare autosomal dominant form of LGMD. Very limited epidemiological data. Prevalence estimated <0.2 per 100k based on genetic registry data.
Extremely rare genetic immunodeficiency. PLAID syndrome (PLCG2-associated lymphoid-predominant inflammation with antibody deficiency), <20 cases reported.

Refractory bladder carcinoma is a specific subtype of bladder cancer. Global bladder cancer incidence ~16 per 100k; refractory cases represent approximately 30% of diagnosed cases, estimated at ~4.8 per 100k. Limited disease-specific epidemiological data available.
Dedifferentiated liposarcoma is rare subtype of soft tissue sarcoma. Recurrence is common but difficult to track separately. Estimated at 0.5 per 100k based on liposarcoma epidemiology.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC); pancreatic cancer surgical literature
column14: Resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma represents approximately 15-20% of pancreatic cancer cases diagnosed (estimated ~2.1 per 100k). Ductal adenocarcinoma comprises ~90% of pancreatic cancers; only 15-20% are resectable at diagnosis, yielding ~2.1 per 100k incidence estimate.

column9: GLOBOCAN 2005 (IARC), with stage-specific estimation
column14: Advanced (stage III-IV) lung carcinoma represents approximately 60-70% of newly diagnosed lung cancers. Using GLOBOCAN 2005 global lung cancer incidence (~40 per 100k), advanced proportion yields ~28.5 per 100k. Note: stage descriptor varies by registry definitions.
MGMT-methylated glioblastoma represents ~40-50% of all glioblastomas (incidence ~3.5-4 per 100k). Estimated ~1.8 per 100k based on methylation frequency from GLOBOCAN and neuro-oncology literature.

Chronic inflammation of stomach and duodenum. Limited incidence data from gastroenterology studies. Using combined metric: incidence ~45 per 100k from endoscopy-based studies; prevalence ~1.2% (~1200 per 100k) from population surveys. Geographic and methodological variation significant. Data quality moderate but limited to developed nations.

Advanced/metastatic prostate cancer incidence estimated at ~8-10 per 100k globally based on ~30 per 100k total prostate cancer incidence (GLOBOCAN 2005 era) with approximately 25-30% presenting as advanced stage. This represents incident cases of advanced disease. Confidence limited by variability in staging definitions and regional diagnostic patterns.

IBD-29 appears to be a specific genetic subtype of inflammatory bowel disease with defined genetic mutations. IBD overall has incidence of 10-20 per 100k, but genetic subtype 29 represents a rare subset, estimated <0.5 per 100k incidence. Confidence low due to limited published epidemiological data on this specific genetic form.
Rare genetic ichthyotic disorder, PSS6 is a specific subtype with <50 cases reported globally, <0.01 per 100k births.
Specific numbered genetic epilepsy (EIEE67) from classified genetic variant discovery. Fewer than 50 cases reported in medical literature. Incidence unmeasurable from population data.

Usher syndrome type IV is an extremely rare genetic variant combining deaf-blindness. Type IV is particularly uncommon with <50 reported cases globally. Estimated <0.005 per 100k based on limited case literature.
Extremely rare skeletal dysplasia, <0.01 per 100k births. Only handful of cases reported in medical literature.
Extremely rare form of complex I deficiency (nuclear-encoded). Type 25 is one of multiple genetic variants with <50 reported cases worldwide, <0.01 per 100k.

Mitochondrial complex I deficiency nuclear type 26 (caused by mutations in NDUFS4 and related genes) is an extremely rare genetic disorder. Fewer than 50 cases documented worldwide. Mitochondrial disorders overall have incidence ~1-2 per 100k, but this specific subtype <0.01 per 100k based on case reports and genetic registries.
Extremely rare form of complex I deficiency (nuclear-encoded). Type 27 is one of multiple genetic variants with <50 reported cases worldwide, <0.01 per 100k.

Extremely rare genetic form of early infantile epileptic encephalopathy. Fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide based on OMIM and literature review. Incidence <0.01 per 100k. Limited epidemiological data, primarily known from genetic case reports.
Rare monogenic epilepsy, benign form with familial inheritance; limited epidemiological data, estimated from genetics literature at <0.01 per 100k births.

Benign Samaritan congenital myopathy is an extremely rare genetic disorder affecting skeletal muscle development. Estimated at <0.01 per 100k births based on case report frequency (likely fewer than 100 cases worldwide). This appears to be a very specific subtype of congenital myopathy with limited epidemiological documentation.
Rare chromosomal disorder (deletion of distal chromosome 12p). Extremely rare with <0.01 per 100k births based on cytogenetic case reports. No systematic epidemiological studies found.

column13: Developmental Delay due to Genetic Disorders
column14: Ultra-rare genetic developmental disorder caused by SOX5 mutations, <20 cases in literature, <0.005 per 100k births.
Rare genetic subtype of SMA with lower extremity predominance. Estimated <0.01 per 100k based on case reports. SMA overall incidence ~1-2 per 100k births; this subtype represents small fraction.
Extremely rare X-linked deletion variant of ABCD1 disorder. <0.01 per 100k births estimated from case report frequency. No systematic epidemiological studies found.
Neonatal-onset form of inflammatory bowel disease; extremely rare genetic variant, <0.01 per 100k, limited case reports in literature.

Rare genetic neuropathy. CMT overall prevalence ~1 in 2500 (~40 per 100k), but this specific autosomal dominant intermediate form with neuropathic pain represents a small subset. Estimated incidence ~0.05 per 100k based on CMT subtype distribution.
Rare chromosomal deletion syndrome, <50 cases reported in literature, estimated <0.01 per 100k births.
